From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,RobbeSneyders,Robbe,mauzhang,Manu Zhang,"Fri, 5 Oct 2018 04:38:08 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:56:11 +0000","Tue, 21 May 2019 16:32:00 +0000",Not applicable,sdk-py-core,,,0,5,16642614,tvalentyn,"Mon, 8 Oct 2018 23:48:57 +0000",

+1. Thanks for filing this issue.

,16645955,tvalentyn,"Thu, 11 Oct 2018 04:21:29 +0000",

Another interesting question is whether we can easily make these suites run in parallel so that we don't slow down precommits too much.

,16645989,mauzhang,"Thu, 11 Oct 2018 05:20:13 +0000",

Do you (or anyone) know how to set up Python version on Jenkins ?

,Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|i3zarg:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,13032866,BEAM-1251,0,0h,21000,5h 50m,Child-Issue,,,,12310460,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,13225754,BEAM-6983,is a child of,,,,,16646940,tvalentyn,"Thu, 11 Oct 2018 19:15:19 +0000","

Hey alanmyrvold, markflyhigh, yifanzou
Do you know how do we configure the version of Python interpreter on Jenkins?
We eventually would like to have multiple versions of the interpreter, so I wonder what the best practices are to achieve that.

One option may be to simply install multiple versions of interpreter on Jenkins machines and rely on tox to discern, another - try to run test suites in a docker container with all necessary dependencies as desired.

Do you have any advice here or perhaps you're working on something similar already?

",16647066,yifanzou,"Thu, 11 Oct 2018 21:45:18 +0000","

AFAIK, the python is installed with ubuntu-1604 in Jenkins slaves that configured by Apache Infra. https://github.com/apache/infrastructure-puppet/blob/deployment/data/ubuntu/ubuntu_1604.yaml.

We do have plans to try running tests in a docker container. https://docs.google.com/document/d/1y0YuQj_oZXC0uM5-gniG7r9-5gv2uiDhzbtgYYJW48c/edit

",16647072,tvalentyn,"Thu, 11 Oct 2018 21:53:41 +0000","

Thanks yifanzou. I think we should find a way to parallelize the test execution, before adding more test suites, since slow precommits will impact developer productivity.

I heard from udim that Bazel has better isolation of test environments and natively supports parallelizing test execution, on test suite and test level.

",16647174,udim,"Thu, 11 Oct 2018 23:25:27 +0000","

My investigation from April 2018 is here: https://github.com/udim/beam/commit/3c08b21a9950e39bf71b150a087ae7bf7350f7c3

I haven't test with cython yet, but I just checked and Bazel has experimental support for pip: https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_python/tree/master/examples/version

",16648346,tvalentyn,"Fri, 12 Oct 2018 19:27:24 +0000",

Lowered the priority to 'Minor' for now - I suggest reserving 'Major' priorities for issues that we must finish for Beam to be viable on Python 3.

,16649237,mauzhang,"Sun, 14 Oct 2018 03:33:06 +0000","

As an experiment, I set up Python 3 environments on travis based on recent master and only Python 3.5 passes among 3.4, 3.5, 3.6 and 3.7.

",,,,,,,Duplicate,13256576,BEAM-8230,duplicates,12310000,16650547,tvalentyn,"Mon, 15 Oct 2018 17:58:25 +0000","

Thanks, mauzhang. Unfortunately I can't see linked test results but if 3.5 is the only suite that passes, it's definitely a concern and a sign that we may want to add testing in other environments sooner than later. To avoid a significant Presubmit slow down, we can start with adding an on-demand Jenkins suite that will run tests in all environments. It would be also great to reach a common understanding what an efficiently parallelizable Beam Python test suite will look like, cc: yifanzou markflyhigh.

",16650919,udim,"Mon, 15 Oct 2018 22:50:36 +0000","

I've summarized my thoughts on running tests using Bazel and Docker here:

https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/4be0f687135b7c6778224dd76389a39f9ebf78a3cf9c4cb4e76ebb73@%3Cdev.beam.apache.org%3E

",16651059,mauzhang,"Tue, 16 Oct 2018 02:40:51 +0000","

tvalentyn, I fixed the travis link and you should be able to see now.

",,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,13225755,BEAM-6984,,,,,,,,,16652621,tvalentyn,"Tue, 16 Oct 2018 23:13:17 +0000","

Thanks, mauzhang. I looked at the logs, and also verifed myself that some tests that pass on Python 3.5 on Jenkins, fail in other versions of the interpreter. FYI matthiasml6 RobbeSneyders splovyt Juta.

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for %: 'bytes' and 'tuple'

",16652629,tvalentyn,"Tue, 16 Oct 2018 23:17:53 +0000","

mauzhang It also seems that your runs also included some tests that we currently skip in Python 3, for example I think 3.4 logs include a skipped test apache_beam.runners.portability.fn_api_runner_test.FnApiRunnerTestWithGrpc.test_pardo_metrics

",16652641,mauzhang,"Tue, 16 Oct 2018 23:23:04 +0000","

tvalentyn, I simply run ""./gradlew testPython3"" for each environment. The Python 3.4 test is much much longer. Is there a flag that doesn't work in 3.4 ?

",16652724,tvalentyn,"Wed, 17 Oct 2018 00:30:18 +0000","

I may be wrong but I suspect for some reason `@unittest.skipif` annotation did not get trigger in your test suite, and then the suite ran into BEAM-5623 which take long to finish. The Travis logs are truncated so I could see if we ran those tests or not.

I tried to run py3 tox test suite from python:3.4-strech conatiner (see: https://s.apache.org/beam-py3-conversion-quick-start) and 117 tests didn't pass. The test suite finished within few minutes.

",16654892,robertwb,"Thu, 18 Oct 2018 09:01:52 +0000","

I don't think 3.4 is important to target (it's already in security-bugfix-only mode). 3.6 and 3.7, yes. 

",16702585,markflyhigh,"Thu, 29 Nov 2018 01:03:34 +0000","

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-17335 is created on Infra team to install other versions of python 3 on Jenkins.

",16709168,tvalentyn,"Tue, 4 Dec 2018 19:26:46 +0000","

Per https://devguide.python.org/, EOL for Python 3.4 is 2019-03-16, so I agree with robertwb that it's no longer important to target.

cc: RobbeSneyders.

",16709190,markflyhigh,"Tue, 4 Dec 2018 19:46:44 +0000",

agree. I'll update the INFRA ticket.

,16734774,mauzhang,"Sat, 5 Jan 2019 04:52:23 +0000","

markflyhigh, tvalentyn and robertwb, it seems there's been no response from the infra for a while. How can we push this forward ?

",16743278,tvalentyn,"Tue, 15 Jan 2019 18:18:36 +0000","

I have reached out to #asfinfra via http://infra.chat, and gmcdonald graciously offered help. Thanks, gmcdonald.

",16826315,yifanzou,"Thu, 25 Apr 2019 18:10:20 +0000","

the beam4 is offline. The OOM is misleading, it is actually caused by some thread leaking. A major leak was fixed in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7109, but seems like there are still other tests eating the thread pool of the VM. I'll keep beam4 offline for investigation. You can rerun the test and it could be assigned to a healthy node.

This issue is assigned but has not received an update in 30 days so it has been labeled ""stale-assigned"". If you are still working on the issue, please give an update and remove the label. If you are no longer working on the issue, please unassign so someone else may work on it. In 7 days the issue will be automatically unassigned.

",17131391,beamjirabot,"Wed, 10 Jun 2020 17:23:53 +0000","

This issue was marked ""stale-assigned"" and has not received a public comment in 7 days. It is now automatically unassigned. If you are still working on it, you can assign it to yourself again. Please also give an update about the status of the work.

",17143004,aromanenko,"Tue, 23 Jun 2020 14:45:25 +0000","

Starting from version 0.13.1, Amazon Kinesis Producer Library (KPL) changed its license to Apache License (https://github.com/awslabs/amazon-kinesis-producer#0130) and current version of KinesisIO.Write already leverage this.

So, we don't need to implement KinesisIO.Write using AWS SDK anymore. Therefore, I close this Jira, feel free to reopen it if you see the other reasons why we should do that.

,16704904,mxm,"Fri, 30 Nov 2018 15:23:21 +0000","

This is caused by executing the state completion request in GrpcStateService asynchronously with the default threadpool. I think this wasn't intended because whenCompleteAsync was used instead of whenComplete. The default thread pool in the test is Flink's thread pool which doesn't take care to log exceptions.
With the current implementation the StateRequest will always be a completed CompleteableFuture anyways, so there is no need to schedule asynchronously.

The following exception was thrown here: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/c526f6bf62a1d63c7181eb7252c134e42d5c8677/runners/java-fn-execution/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/fnexecution/state/GrpcStateService.java#L85

",16705109,lcwik,"Fri, 30 Nov 2018 18:12:48 +0000","

By default, gRPC provides outbound stream observers that aren't thread safe (for perf reasons) and expects people interacting with them to make them thread safe. The issue seems to be that GrpcStateService assumes that the outbound stream observer is thread safe but by default it is not.

In addition to what you have added, we should also make the GrpcStateService take in an OutboundObserverFactory that allows the person constructing it to choose whether they want a ""buffered and thread safe outbound observer"" or a ""non thread safe (aka direct)"" observer and then the GrpcStateService will provide the necessary hooks for allowing runners to choose whether state requests are handled in parallel or not.

[BEAM-8747] Remove Unused non-vendored Guava compile dependencies,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8747,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

kenn says:

BeamModulePlugin just contains lists of versions to ease coordination across Beam modules, but mostly does not create dependencies. Most of Beam's modules only depend on a few things there. For example Guava is not a core dependency, but here is where it is actually depended upon:
These results appear to be misleading. Grepping for 'import com.google.common', I see this as the actual state of things:
• GCP connector does not appear to actually depend on Guava in compile scope
• The Beam SQL JDBC driver does not appear to actually depend on Guava in compile scope
• The Dataflow Java worker does depend on Guava at compile scope but has incorrect dependencies (and it probably shouldn't)
• KinesisIO does depend on Guava at compile scope but has incorrect dependencies (Kinesis libs have Guava on API surface so it is OK here, but should be correctly declared)
• ZetaSQL translator does depend on Guava at compile scope but has incorrect dependencies (ZetaSQL has it on API surface so it is OK here, but should be correctly declared)
We used to have an analysis that prevented this class of error.

Once the errors are fixed, the guava_version is simply a version that we have discovered that seems to work for both Kinesis and ZetaSQL, libraries we do not control. Kinesis producer is built against 18.0. Kinesis client against 26.0-jre. ZetaSQL against 26.0-android.
(or maybe I messed up in my analysis)

Kenn

From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,yifanzou,Yifan Zou,suztomo,Tomo Suzuki,"Tue, 12 Nov 2019 17:39:25 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:55:53 +0000","Wed, 13 Nov 2019 01:22:36 +0000",2.18.0,build-system,,,0,2,16972670,yifanzou,"Tue, 12 Nov 2019 18:01:50 +0000","

I ran the plugin on my local and got the same results as Jenkins log. Might because environmental settings lead to different behaviors of the plugin. suztomo Would you provide more info of your local environment? Such as the gradle version, which directory you've run the command in, and anything you suspect that may cause the problem? Thanks. 

",16972709,suztomo,"Tue, 12 Nov 2019 19:17:32 +0000","

I ran the runBeamDependencyCheck at the root of Git-cloned directory (""src"" in my case). The gradlew shows  5.2.1. Copied detailed output:

https://gist.github.com/suztomo/1460f2be48025c8ea764e86a2c6e39a8

",16972907,yifanzou,"Wed, 13 Nov 2019 00:00:16 +0000","

The problem is that Jenkins runs `gradle :runBeamDependencyCheck`. When the Gradle runs tasks with colons (aka. qualified names), then the path is resolved relative to the root project. In our case, it only checks dependencies defined in the root directory. Removing the "":"" from the task name will lead to a multi-project build. https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/10079 will fix this issue.

[BEAM-5921] [SQL] Support Joda types for UDF arguments,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-5921,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

We call ScalarFunctionImpl.create() to register a UDF with Calcite schema in BeamSqlEnv. Internally it uses Calcite's internal mapping (JavaToSqlTypeConversionRules) to map Java types to SQL types to create a function signature that gets registered in the schema. Problem is that this logic is not extensible and doesn't include Joda types support (maybe others as well).

We can work around this by constructing our own subclass of Function that gets registered in the schema instead of calling ScalarFunctionImpl.create(). This logic can use our own custom mapping (or fall back to Calcite implementation if needed).

eblanchi_cni pointed out that we have 'pyyaml>
column3: 4.0.0' in the python sdk, which is impacting other libraries (such as googleads). Would we bring it up to at least pyyaml 5.1?

column1:
cc: eblanchi_cni

",16941133,bhulette,"Mon, 30 Sep 2019 16:56:40 +0000","

I searched in the repo and it looks like there are actually only two places where we use pyyaml, both in tests (to read trigger_transcripts.yaml, and standard_coders.yaml). Could we also make this a test dependency?

",16941135,bhulette,"Mon, 30 Sep 2019 16:57:58 +0000","

eblanchi_cni also pointed out that there was a security flaw in pyyaml, resolved in 5.1. Details here https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/207

From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,tvalentyn,Valentyn Tymofieiev,tvalentyn,Valentyn Tymofieiev,"Tue, 26 Feb 2019 17:22:26 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:55:13 +0000","Mon, 11 Mar 2019 19:27:31 +0000",Not applicable,sdk-py-core,,,0,1,16784093,tvalentyn,"Tue, 5 Mar 2019 05:21:52 +0000","

I suspect the problem here  may be with the test.

Adding some debug output  at  https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/af2e5bd8a42ea0eb7ce12ea29b8a32757accc197/sdks/python/apache_beam/io/avroio.py#L465 , we can see that on Python 3 block.size is roughly 16000 (bytes?), while on Python 2 it is roughly 64000.  Exact numbers slightly vary, but it think there is some implementation detail in fastavro library that on Python 2 makes a default block size to be <
So on Python 3 we have 3 blocks total, while on Python 3 we have 11 blocks.
The test assumes that there are always 3 blocks: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/af2e5bd8a42ea0eb7ce12ea29b8a32757accc197/sdks/python/apache_beam/io/avroio_test.py#L302.

chamikara, do you know how does fastavro.read.block_reader selects block size? Are there any requirements or guarantees that dictate a certain size, or it may be implementation/platform-dependent?

[BEAM-5799] Investigate the root cause of session_end is always equal to session_start,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-5799,12319527,BEAM,Beam,,,13192983,BEAM-5799,Investigate the root cause of session_end is always equal to session_start,1,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21133&avatarType=issuetype,Bug,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,10003,Resolved,amaliujia,Rui Wang,amaliujia,Rui Wang,"Fri, 19 Oct 2018 22:31:29 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:55:11 +0000","Tue, 23 Oct 2018 21:52:23 +0000",Not applicable,dsl-sql,,,0,1,16661348,amaliujia,"Tue, 23 Oct 2018 21:51:40 +0000","

Why we are not missing tumble_end and hop_end?

Because when generating logical plan, Calcite replaces tumble_start and hop_start with a reference to GROUP BY's TUMBLE/HOP. The GROUP BY's TUMBLE/HOP is supposed to return a timestamp. Then Calcite replaces tumble_end and hop_end with a PLUS(timestamp reference, window_size as a constant). As tumble and hop has a fixed window size as constants in their function signatures, Calcite generates the PLUS in logical plan, which means for tumble and hop, we only need a timestamp (which represents window_start in our implementation) to generate both window_start and window_end in Projection.

We are emitting window_start timestamp as the result of TUMBLE/HOP/SESSION functions: https://github.com/amaliujia/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/transform/BeamAggregationTransforms.java#L84

Because Calcite does not know what's the window size of session window, so in logical plan, Calcite generates a reference to GROUP BY's SESSION for session_end, as the same as the reference generated for session_start. So in logical plan, session_start = session_end. Because in BeamSQL, we don't differentiate session with tumble and hop, and we returns window start as the result of SESSION function, so in the final result, we see session_start = session_end.
Clearly Calcite shouldn't hide window_end in logical plan. Ideally Calcite should keep window_end in logical plan and let us decide what does it mean: either a reference or a PLUS or something else.

However, Calcite leaves space for us to change the window_end back in physical plan nodes. For example, we can add window_end back in BeamAggregateRel. We can probably change the reference of session_end to a reference to our window_end in BeamAggregateRel.

In BeamAggregateRel, we should add a window_end right after window functions. We can emit window end timestamp for the added field. And in Projection, we should change window_end from a PLUS (for tumble and hop) and a wrong reference (for session) to a right reference to the newly added window_end in Aggregation.

The GeneralTriggerDriver does not put watermark holds on timers, leading to the ontime empty pane being considered late data.

Fix: Add a new notion of whether a trigger has an ontime pane. If it does, then set a watermark hold to end of window - 1.

[BEAM-7188] LTS backport: FlinkRunner does not checkpoint partition view of watermark holds,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7188,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

The FlinkRunner does not persist its view of the per-partition Watermark holds. This can lead to elements to be considered late after restoring from a savepoint or resuming a failed pipeline.

Similar to the approach in BEAM-6650, we can recover the Watermarks by iterating through the keys of the state backend during recovery.

[BEAM-8616] ParquetIO should have Hadoop dependencies as provided,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8616,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

ParquetIO has the hadoop-client dependency as a compile-time dependency however this dependency should be provided by the user as defined in parquet-hadoop. By pinning a hadoop version we are limiting users from providing different Hadoop jars (as they can with native Parquet), it also limits us from providing different hadoop versions to test that the Parquet module is compatible with Hadoop 3 (when it will).

Note this is a 'backwards incompatible' change in the sense that users might need to explicitly provide the dependency from now on.

",,13267652,BEAM-8616,ParquetIO should have Hadoop dependencies as provided,7,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21146&avatarType=issuetype,Sub-task,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. ",16973438,iemejia,"Wed, 13 Nov 2019 15:20:21 +0000","

It is, we have a similar change already on Kafka, for details: BEAM-3620

However we need to make this explicit in the release notes I think we have a label for this. Impact for end users is the need to explicitly add the hadoop-client dependency in their projects if they already don't have it in their clusters.

iemejia I agree, however, I can't find the label - which one do you have in mind?

[BEAM-6746] Support DoFn.setup and DoFn.teardown in Python,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6746,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

DoFn.setup and DoFn.teardown is currently supported in Java but not Python. These would be useful for performing expensive per-thread initialization.
While lazy initialization is a usable workaround, first class support for setup and teardown would encourage consistent conventions and make the API more uniform with the Java version.

This is related to BEAM-3736 (same issue, but for CombineFn).

[BEAM-7884] Run pylint in Python 3,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7884,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Currently run_pylint.sh only runs in tox environment py27-lint.
py35-lint uses another script named run_mini_py3lint.sh.

1. Make run_pylint.sh run and pass for py35-lint. Might have to add some ignores to .pylintrc (such as useless-object-inheritance), and might have to rename some deprecated functions (such as s/assertRaisesRegexp/assertRaisesRegex/).
2. Make sure all tests in run_mini_py3lint.sh are in run_pylint.sh and remove run_mini_py3lint.sh.

3. (optional) Remove py27-lint?

[BEAM-7269] Remove StateSpec from hashCode of SimpleStateTag,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7269,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

SimpleStateTag is used as key in hash based StateTable, and currently is hashes and compares StateSpec and StructuredId, that are inside the SimpleStateTag. StateSpec hashes Coder into the resulting hashCode and when the Coder fails to have a proper hashCode and equals implementations, it results in wrong behavior (apparently missing states).

With Flink 1.10 around the corner, more detail can be found in BEAM-9295, we should consider dropping support for Flink 1.7. Then dropping 1.7 will also decrease the build time.

What do you think?

mxm thw agree? Worth to discuss in the mailing list IMO

",17034809,thw,"Tue, 11 Feb 2020 20:21:01 +0000","

iemejia yes, this should be on the mailing list. IMO good to communicate intent to dev@ and user@ and also refer to https://beam.apache.org/documentation/runners/flink/#version-compatibility

",17035890,sunjincheng121,"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 03:42:44 +0000","

Thanks for the reminder iemejia and thw !

I prefer maintain at most three(Even maintaining two is reasonable) versions of Flink runner for Apache Beam community, because Apache Flink only support the current and previous minor release with bugfixes, more detail can be found in [
column3: . So, I think its better to maintain the three versions of 1.8/1.9/1.10 after add Flink v1.10 build target to Flink runner.

column1: I'm not sure if it deserves a discussion in the mailing list as it seems that we already maintain 3 versions of Flink runner in Beam now. Removing Flink runner 1.7 seems straightward if we upgrade Flink runner to 1.10. However, I'm not sure what's the policy before and it's great to also hear mxm 's suggestions?

column3:
https://flink.apache.org/downloads.html#update-policy-for-old-releases

",Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|z0bdwg:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,,,0,0h,7800,2h 10m,Blocker,13284655,BEAM-9295,blocks,10032,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,17036121,mxm,"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 10:32:48 +0000","

+1 to removing 1.7

column1:
It's a good idea to announce this on the mailing list, prior to the removal. It'll help to communicate the change in case any users are still relying on the build.

",17039079,sunjincheng121,"Tue, 18 Feb 2020 13:24:59 +0000","

Thanks for the confirm mxm

Because the code of Flink 1.7 is too old, the current existence of Flink runner 1.7 will affect the upgrade of Flink runner 1.8x and 1.9x , more detail can be found in BEAM-9299, so we need to remove the support of Flink runner 1.7 as soon as possible. and I'll bring up the DISCUSSION soon，and open the PR ASAP.

",17039129,sunjincheng121,"Tue, 18 Feb 2020 14:37:18 +0000","

huygaa chamikara charleschen: Do you know how to reliably identify a relevant Dataflow job ID for a failed integration test from a stream of Jenkins test logs? In this case, for: test_leader_board_it (apache_beam.examples.complete.game.leader_board_it_test.LeaderBoardIT).

",16730493,tvalentyn,"Fri, 28 Dec 2018 22:55:42 +0000","

This bug was originally opened a flake, but we could not correlate the flake with a failing job ID from the logs. Looks like  now logs give more information, so let's focus this Jira on a last failure with similar symptom, pointed out by apilloud, that has clear indication of a failing job.
Logs have several messages of the form:
E Missing required coder_id on grpc_port for -11
I No unique name set for transform -11
Then the test times out. Assigning to robertwb who added the ""Missing required coder_id"" error message and is investigating a similar issue.

",16730494,tvalentyn,"Fri, 28 Dec 2018 22:57:03 +0000","

cc: altay

",17034684,tvalentyn,"Tue, 11 Feb 2020 18:18:28 +0000","

Missing required coder_id messages messages are not critical, the issue is a duplicate of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-4150.

[BEAM-9901] Beam python nexmark benchmark suite,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-9901,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Nexmark is a suite of queries (pipelines) used to measure performance and non-regression in Beam. Currently it exists in java sdk: https://github.com/apache/beam/tree/master/sdks/java/testing/nexmark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/nexmark

In this project we would like to create the nexmark benchmark suite in python sdk equivalent to what BEAM has for java. This allows us to determine performance impact on pull requests for python pipelines.

",,13303166,BEAM-9901,Beam python nexmark benchmark suite,3,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21148&avatarType=issuetype,Task,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. ",17102041,iemejia,"Thu, 7 May 2020 21:21:59 +0000","

I suggest to ignore the generator part and focus on advancing the write and execution of the quries. Java's generator can be used in a first instance to export data into both Pubsub and GCS. Also running the queries from the generated data would give us a more standard baseline to compare performance of similar queries between portable and non portable runners.

[BEAM-7868] Hidden Flink Runner parameters are dropped in python pipelines,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7868,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Hidden pipeline options for Portable flink runner are not interpreted by Python SDK.

An example of this is ManualDockerEnvironmentOptions.getRetainDockerContainers which is not interpreted in python sdk.

",,13248236,BEAM-7868,Hidden Flink Runner parameters are dropped in python pipelines,1,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21133&avatarType=issuetype,Bug,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,angoenka,Ankur Goenka,angoenka,Ankur Goenka,"Thu, 1 Aug 2019 02:10:14 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:54:14 +0000","Wed, 10 Jun 2020 17:59:36 +0000",2.19.0,runner-flink,,,0,3,16897698,angoenka,"Thu, 1 Aug 2019 02:11:43 +0000","

cc: thw hulettbh 

",16897703,thw,"Thu, 1 Aug 2019 02:16:43 +0000","

What means ""hidden"" and what do you expect to happen?
which can mark the pipeline options to be hidden example ManualDockerEnvironmentOptions
These hidden pipeline options are not returned in PipelineOptionsFactory.describe which is used by Python SDK in PortableRunner ( job_service.DescribePipelineOptions )

And here the unknown hidden options are dropped by SDK.

[BEAM-10027] Support for Kotlin-based Beam Katas,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-10027,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Currently, there are a series of examples available demonstrating the use of Apache Beam with Kotlin. It would be nice to have support for the same Beam Katas that exist for Python, Go, and Java to also support Kotlin.

The port itself shouldn't be that involved since it can still target the JVM, so it would likely just require the inclusion for Kotlin dependencies and a conversion for all of the existing Java examples. 

",,13305727,BEAM-10027,Support for Kotlin-based Beam Katas,4,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21140&avatarType=issuetype,Improvement,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,11,Done,rionmonster,Rion Williams,rionmonster,Rion Williams,"Mon, 18 May 2020 17:43:37 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:54:10 +0000","Sat, 6 Jun 2020 18:09:08 +0000",2.23.0,katas,,,0,2,17110495,rionmonster,"Mon, 18 May 2020 17:46:00 +0000","

Any feedback on this issue would be welcome with regards to implementation or a preferred method for going about implementing it. I've worked with Kotlin as a primary language when using Beam and have previously converted [the existing Stepik Beam Katas - Java course|https://stepik.org/course/54530] internally for myself and my team to work through, so it'd be great to share with the community.

",17112395,rionmonster,"Wed, 20 May 2020 16:08:46 +0000","

Pull Request
You can [find a pull request related to this feature here|https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/11761] that will detail all of the major changes introduced that can be summarized below:
• Added appropriate Kotlin-based dependencies for gradle (specific to the Kotlin Katas directory)
• Converted all existing .java tasks files over to Kotlin (e.g. .kt) and updated all of the placeholders where applicable
• Verified that all of the unit tests backing the tasks are passing as expected using the existing input.
• Removed all of the original course metadata (e.g. `*-remote-info.yaml files) assuming that the creation of a new course will overwrite these.

Do you know the appropriate fix version to apply to this? It was merged in yesterday so I wanted to make sure that the ticket was appropriately closed and versioned.

",16773266,tvalentyn,"Wed, 20 Feb 2019 18:43:34 +0000","

Error messages like ""GET /v1.27/ ... json returned error: No such image: gcr.io/cloud-dataflow/v1beta3/... "" are a common Dataflow red herring, they often appear when an image that is referenced in the log is not yet cached in local Docker repository in Dataflow worker VM, and was not yet pulled from external repository (gcr.io). However, in most cases, after seeing this error, Dataflow worker will fetch the image from GCR and pipeline resumes.

It is a common and, unfortunately, misleading message that users may see when migrating to a new Beam SDK, since it takes some time for Dataflow workers to pick up container images used by most recent Beam SDK. However in most cases this is not a true error.
To confirm that this message is indeed a red herring and not a permanent error we can run a docker command to pull this image ourselves:

In rare cases such as when network on Dataflow workers is restricted or there is GCR.io outage, this error will cause the pipeline to fail. However in most cases, pipeline fails for some other reason.

",16773267,tvalentyn,"Wed, 20 Feb 2019 18:45:28 +0000","

As to the first message on this issue, we need to find out why the job gets stuck after an hour. A user may reach out to Dataflow customer support to assist with investigation, see: https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/support.

",16773356,arpi,"Wed, 20 Feb 2019 20:07:05 +0000","

tvalentyn should the caching work with custom images stored on gcr.io as well? This is a private image, stored in a bucket in the same project as the Dataflow work itself.

I saw that the error message was repeated over the span of 30-60 minutes, then the job was cancelled due to stuckness.

",16773376,tvalentyn,"Wed, 20 Feb 2019 20:41:59 +0000","

arpi, it sounds like you would like to pass a custom container image, on Dataflow side this functionality is supported only Portable Pipeline execution model (that uses FnAPI). Python streaming and Go pipelines would always use this execution model in Dataflow runner.
Custom containers currently are always pulled at runtime from GCR, since a custom container is not present on the VM image used by Dataflow worker.

If SDK is using a legacy execution mode, for example a typical Java Batch pipeline, passing a custom worker harness container image is currently disallowed by Dataflow service. 

",16773628,kenn,"Thu, 21 Feb 2019 03:19:25 +0000",

I expect these are two different issues.

,,,,,,,,,,,,16773630,kenn,"Thu, 21 Feb 2019 03:24:19 +0000","

",16774291,tvalentyn,"Thu, 21 Feb 2019 16:41:48 +0000","

kenn, I would say that there isn't enough sufficient information in this thread to determine rootcause of the issue, and one needs to investigate further why the Dataflow pipeline is stuck. The first message and one by mattcasters_neo4j are concerning since seems like migration from 2.9.0 to 2.10.0 is at least not smooth, but there is also not enough information in this thread to understand the rootcause.

Thanks for your help

[BEAM-7474] Add SDK harness containers for Py 3.6, Py 3.7,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7474,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Currently we can build a Py3-compatible container image with gradle by running:
This builds a docker container image like: valentyn-docker-apache.bintray.io/beam/python3
The code for this is defined in: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/ae60a72b03f3a2b6b2a06667ec1868a7acc8e38f/sdks/python/container/py3/build.gradle#L48

To support portable runners that use a container (e.g. Flink) on multiple versions of Python 3, we should make it possible to build Python 3-compatible SDK harness containers bundled with any desired python version.
The only difference right now would be the base image used in FROM field in Dockerfile.
Alternatively, we could have one parameterized Dockerfile that starts with :
I think the latter approach, may result in complications later if these containers will need to diverge down the road.

cc'ing a few folks who may have some feedback on this: angoenka mxm robertwb Juta frederik.

I prefer a parameterized docker file
column2:
it prevents accidental divergence.

,16854359,mxm,"Mon, 3 Jun 2019 08:27:17 +0000","

I second Robert, let's go with the parameterized approach first. If we later discover that the base image cannot be shared across all Python versions, we can still introduce separate Dockerfiles.

column1:
Btw, how important is having multiple Python 3.x versions? Wouldn't it suffice to have the latest Python version, e.g. 3.7.x?

",16854391,robertwb,"Mon, 3 Jun 2019 08:57:23 +0000","

Point releases are not necessarily fully backwards compatible (though generally much, much more so that 2.x to 3.x), so it's valuable to have both (especially as we count on things like pickling compatibility which is an internal implementation detail).

Also of note, 3.5 is nearly end-of-life, but 3.8 is on on the horizon.

",Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|z03bj4:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,13032866,BEAM-1251,,,,,Incorporates,,,,12310010,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,13249191,BEAM-7907,is part of,,,,,16865975,tvalentyn,"Mon, 17 Jun 2019 20:43:57 +0000","

frederik, you can test your changes by building a container image, for example, ./gradlew :sdks:python:container:py3:docker, and running ValidatesContainer suites, for example: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/7e633f34e3a8ee68274d2752382fb6a52b5e9b4a/.test-infra/jenkins/job_PostCommit_Python_ValidatesContainer_Dataflow.groovy#L25. The latter suite currently does not pass due to BEAM-7063, but you could still try to exercise the container with Portable Python Precommit suite, see https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/8745/files#diff-08a37e2757c9df3f0e1d0ba3e2121eecR101.

Portable Python Precommit suite is currently flaky (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7546), so I don't think we should run it for all of 3.5 - 3.7, but we could switch Portable Python Precommit from Python 3.5 to 3.7 after this issue is completed and/or to help test the changes being made here.

[BEAM-6133] [SQL] Add support for TableMacro UDF,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6133,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Now we support only ScalarFunction UDFs. In Calcite, there are other kinds of UDFs. With TableMacro UDFs users can connect external data sources in a similar way as in TableProvider, but without specifying a schema, or enumerating a list of existing tables in advance.
An example use case is connecting external metadata service and querying range of partitions.
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM table(my_udf('dataset', start = '2017-01-01', end = '2018-01-01'))

Where the implementation of `my_udf` will connect to this service, get file locations for a range of partitions, and translate to PTransform reading it.

[BEAM-8582] Python SDK emits duplicate records for Default and AfterWatermark triggers,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8582,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

This was found after fixing https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8581. The fix for 8581 was to pass in the input watermark. Previously, it was using MIN_TIMESTAMP for all of its EOW calculations. By giving it a proper input watermark, this bug started to manifest.
The DefaultTrigger and AfterWatermark do not clear their timers after the watermark passed the end of the endow, leading to duplicate records being emitted.

Fix: Clear the watermark timer when the watermark reaches the end of the window.

[BEAM-8792] Bring back the names of the runtime metrics to "runtime",https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8792,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Since this PR (https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/8941), the names of the runtime metrics defined in Python load tests pipelines have changed to a combination of metrics namespace and ""runtime"". This made querying BigQuery table containing the results more difficult. The goal is to bring back the names of the metrics to ""runtime"" to stay concise with the previous records.

[BEAM-7148] LTS backport: AfterProcessingTime trigger doesn't fire reliably,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7148,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Issue
Beam AfterProcessingTime trigger doesn't fire always reliably after a configured delay.
The following job triggers should fire after watermark passes the end of the window and then every 5 seconds for late data and the finally at the end of allowed lateness.
Late firing after processing time trigger should fire after 5 seconds since first late records arrive in the pane.

From my testings late triggers works for some keys but not for the other - it's pretty random which keys are affected. The DummySource generates 15 distinct keys AA,BB,..., PP. For each key it sends 5 on time records and one late record. In case late trigger firing is missed it won't fire until the allowed lateness period.
public void process(ProcessContext context, BoundedWindow window) {
LOG.info(""Count: {}. For window {}, Pane {}"", context.element(), window, context.pane())
I've created a github repo https://github.com/pbartoszek/BEAM-3863_late_trigger with the code shown above. Please check out the README file for details how to replicate the issue.

[BEAM-8657] Not doing Combiner lifting for data-driven triggers,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8657,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

The test below will always produce empty output, due to combiner lifting, which already combines all input values of one shard into one before grouping. To fix this, we shall not do Combiner lifting for the data-driven triggers.

column3:
beam.WindowInto(FixedWindows(6), trigger=trigger.AfterCount(2), accumulation_mode=trigger.AccumulationMode.DISCARDING) | beam.CombinePerKey(combine.Largest(1)))

[BEAM-6981] :beam-sdks-java-javadoc:aggregateJavadoc has no encoding set,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6981,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Beams javadoc project does not apply beam module plugin.
As rhe aggregateJavadoc tasks configuration does not set
and the option is also not inherited from beam modules applyJavaNature current javadoc creation relies on systems default file encoding (or whatever happens to be active for the jvm)

So we either need to set it explicitly, or apply our plugin. The latter is probably better, as it ensures all configuration globally set for java projects will be used.

",16939450,łukaszg,"Fri, 27 Sep 2019 13:26:08 +0000","

I think we need to upgrade errorprone if we want to be able to build the project with java11. I'm currently facing problems with guava described in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-5085.
Errorprone fail on JDK 11 described here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-8319

[BEAM-7099] Performance tests environment setup failed on new Jenkins nodes,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7099,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

This setup failure affects all performance tests. Error in pip install step shows:
00:00:22.772 Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
00:00:22.772 This backport is for Python 2.7 only.
00:00:22.820 Command ""python setup.py egg_info"" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-install-lq5qnijw/functools32/
It installs a 2.7 only package in non-2.7 environment. Since virtualenv is installed by pip3 on new Jenkins nodes, the default py version is python3:

Need to specify python2.7 in this case. Fix in https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/8336.

Query 1: What are the bid values in Euro's? (Currency Conversion)
Query 2: Find bids with specific auction ids and show their bid price.

Query 4: What is the average selling price for each auction category?
Query 5: Which auctions have seen the most bids in the last period?

GcpApiSurfaceTest fails:
but: The following white-listed scopes did not have matching classes on the API surface:
The following code in ApiSurface made abandonedClassMatchers nonempty. getExposedToExposers tells ""A map from exposed types to place where they are exposed"".

column7: exposedToExposers = getExposedToExposers() seems to be useful to identify exposer classes. Also {{apiSurface

column1: Explanation of the Change in API Surface
This removed the ResourceName from exposed classes.
com.google.bigtable.admin.v2 package had exposed class com.google.bigtable.admin.v2.InstanceName in bigtable-client-core 1.8.0. Path to the class:
BigtableInstanceName dropped toAdminInstanceName method in January 2019. https://github.com/googleapis/java-bigtable-hbase/pull/2043/files#diff-36056d6784a87e2537c8ba1864c4d9f2L130

Returns a value that consists of original_value appended with pattern. The return_length is an INT64 that specifies the length of the returned value. If original_value is BYTES, return_length is the number of bytes. If original_value is STRING, return_length is the number of characters.
The default value of pattern is a blank space.
Both original_value and pattern must be the same data type.
If return_length is less than or equal to the original_value length, this function returns the original_value value, truncated to the value of return_length. For example, RPAD(""hello world"", 7)
If original_value, return_length, or pattern is NULL, this function returns NULL.

STRUCT('abc' AS t, 8 AS len, 'def' AS pattern),

[BEAM-6114] SQL join selection should be done in planner, not in expansion to PTransform,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6114,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Currently Beam SQL joins all go through a single physical operator which has a single PTransform that does all join algorithms based on properties of its input PCollections as well as the relational algebra.
A first step is to make the needed information part of the relational algebra, so it can choose a PTransform based on that, and the PTransforms can be simpler.

Second step is to have separate (physical) relational operators for different join algorithms.

",,13199996,BEAM-6114,"SQL join selection should be done in planner, not in expansion to PTransform",4,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21140&avatarType=issuetype,Improvement,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. ",16897371,rahul8383,"Wed, 31 Jul 2019 17:33:59 +0000","

amaliujia
I will add 3 converter rules with predicates to identify the type of Join.
The predicate for SideInputJoin: One Bounded Input, One Unbounded Input
The predicate for SideInputLookupJoin: One Seekable Input, One Non-Seekable Input
The predicate for StandardJoin: Both Bounded Inputs (or) Both Unbounded Inputs
These three Predicates will cover all the possible Joins, right?
We have to add cost for each Rel so that the least cost Rel is chosen when more than one rules match. For Example [
column2: One Bounded Seekable Input, One Unbounded Input&#93
column3: match both the Predicates for SideInputJoin and SideInputLookupJoin. So, by providing costs in increasing order for SideInputLookupJoin, SideInputJoin, StandardJoin SideInputLookupJoin will be used for the above case.

column1: For the Unsupported Join operations such as FULL OUTER Join for SideInputJoin, an UnsupportedOperationException will be thrown in BeamSideInputJoinRel.java

I will add isView as part of BEAM-7835

I have been exploring RelOptRule and ConverterRule. This is the summary of my Exploration:
As we want to convert from ""Convention.None"" to ""BeamLogicalConvention.INSTANCE"", we cannot use RelOptRule, which is used for Optimizing the Query by modifying the order of Rel expressions.
Coming to ConverterRule, currently, there is no way to match a ConverterRule based on operands(like RelOptRule, where a rule can be matched by specifying the children[
column2: I was thinking that we can specify BeamRelNode as two child nodes of LogicalJoin&#93
column3: of the RelNodes in the Constructor).

column1: One way to create a ConverterRule for each type of join is to Implement a predicate on LogicalJoin RelNode by following these steps:

• Convert input RelNodes to BeamRelNodes, if inputs are not already an instance of BeamRelNode. To convert from RelNode to BeamRelNode, we have to find the type of Relnode and accordingly create instances of BeamRelNode.
• Check for Boundedness of the inputs and convert to specific BeamJoinRel Instance.

Do you prefer a better approach?

",16913924,amaliujia,"Fri, 23 Aug 2019 04:43:37 +0000","

rahul8383
Regarding to : // Should we throw Exception when joinType is LEFT (or) RIGHT (or) FULL?

My perspective is, for the sake of simplicity, we can only allow triggering once (like what CoGBK is doing). By doing so, we will allow LEFT/RIGHT/FULL OUTER join. It is because for multiple triggering, the problem is how to refine data. Think about outer join means it could emit <
column3: at the first triggering and later it will have to emit &lt
column5: to refine data. We will need retractions to solve this problem.

column1:
Also it sounds nice to split javadoc of BeamJoinRel. Thanks for bringing it up.

",16914456,rahul8383,"Fri, 23 Aug 2019 16:43:38 +0000","

amaliujia
My understanding is that, even with allowing triggering once, for SideInputLookupJoin,
• LEFT OUTER Join is not supported when the left side of the join is Seekable
• RIGHT OUTER Join is not supported when the right side of the join is Seekable.

This is similar to SideInputJoin where we are throwing exceptions for UnSupported Join types. But there are no such exceptions for SideInputLookupJoin. So, I wanted to know if it is okay to throw Exceptions for SideInputLookupJoin for unsupported Join Types.

",16914519,amaliujia,"Fri, 23 Aug 2019 18:03:11 +0000","

Sorry Rahul. I must have thought something else when replied you last night.
Regarding to SideInputLookupJoin, I am thinking to separate boundness on non-seekable side.
For seekable join bounded: all types should be supported because you will see all data (which also means emitting once).
For seekable join unbounded: same as side input join.

In the future when we support retractions, we could support outer joins on the seekable side as we can retract results(but it might be less piratical to do so)

",16914535,rahul8383,"Fri, 23 Aug 2019 18:27:16 +0000","

To support all types of Joins with Seekable Join Bounded, we have to enhance BeamJoinTransforms.JoinAsLookup as the current logic for LookupJoin, doesn't take care of all the join types.
We also have to introduce a method in BeamSqlSeekableTable to get all the rows.

I think Once triggering will also apply to Unbounded data with Default Trigger.

",16914549,amaliujia,"Fri, 23 Aug 2019 19:16:08 +0000","

You are right. There are enhancements required to support all join types for Seekable Join Bounded, especially on the seekable table interface (which however is not the goal for the seekable interface to return all rows).

",16734713,altay,"Sat, 5 Jan 2019 00:53:17 +0000","

tvalentyn could you take a look at this one? I suspect it is still related to PyPI related issues. Perhaps we need to add a retry because with the number of tests even small issues with pypi will result in multiple flakes

",16734714,tvalentyn,"Sat, 5 Jan 2019 00:55:29 +0000","

Sure, I'll take a look.

",16743487,tvalentyn,"Wed, 16 Jan 2019 00:28:57 +0000","

https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/7519 increases number of retries pip should attempt.
If  the nature of the failure is such that  pip cannot access pypi, this PR might help, because now pip will retry 10 times over the course of 4 min.

If the nature of the failure is such that pypi sends a valid but incorrect response, the PR might not help, because pip won't consider that a retry is necessary. In this case we may have to add a retry call to pip itself.

I'm going to close the issue until we see the next instance of this flake.

[BEAM-9085] Performance regression in np.random.RandomState() skews performance test results across Python 2/3 on Dataflow,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-9085,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Tests show that the performance of core Beam operations in Python 3.x on Dataflow can be a few time slower than in Python 2.7. We should investigate what's the cause of the problem.
Currently, we have one ParDo test that is run both in Py3 and Py2 [
column3: . A dashboard with runtime results can be found here [

https://apache-beam-testing.appspot.com/explore?dashboard=5678187241537536

From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,kamilwu,Kamil Wasilewski,kamilwu,Kamil Wasilewski,"Fri, 10 Jan 2020 12:15:55 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:52:56 +0000","Wed, 15 Apr 2020 21:16:50 +0000",Not applicable,testing,,,0,2,17027900,tvalentyn,"Sat, 1 Feb 2020 00:09:35 +0000","

It appears that the increase in time is likely caused by either generating the synthetic input, or reading the synthetic input.

column1: The problem can be reproduced on Direct runner as well, I don't think it's Dataflow-specific.
Following command shows 14 (Py2) vs 40 (Py3) seconds difference on my machine.

",17028916,kamilwu,"Mon, 3 Feb 2020 13:03:27 +0000",

Thanks. I guess now we should do some profiling on `SyntheticSource` and find bottlenecks.

,17029183,tvalentyn,"Mon, 3 Feb 2020 18:49:06 +0000","

I did some profiling on direct runner using cprofile. The direct runner slowdown might be caused by some inefficiency in threading model, or other concurrency issue.
ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)

It is possible that Dataflow runner the slowdown manfiests via a different way, since it does not use fn_api_runner.py.

",Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|z0adu8:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,,,0,0h,33600,9h 20m,Child-Issue,,,,12310460,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,13268576,BEAM-8671,is a child of,,,,,17029201,tvalentyn,"Mon, 3 Feb 2020 18:59:21 +0000","

",17035914,tvalentyn,"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 04:44:22 +0000","

This is a regression in numpy. Downgrading numpy to 1.16.5 produces the same results for me on Py 2 / Py 3.

column2: [1 loop, best of 5: 1.22 sec per loop
1 loop, best of 5: 17.8 msec per loop

column1: Beam uses np.random.RandomState() during generation of Synthetic input[
Note that 1.16.5 is the latest numpy version with Python 2 support, but on Python 3 newer versions are available.

column5: The RandomState provides access to legacy generators. This generator is considered frozen and will have no further improvements. It is guaranteed to produce the same values as the final point release of NumPy v1.16. [
column7: . This class should only be used if it is essential to have randoms that are identical to what would have been produced by previous versions of NumPy.

column1: kamilwu, would you have time to investigate which replacement generator we can use for consistent performance on 1.16.5 and 1.18.1? If such generator is not available, we can downgrade numpy via supplying a requirements.txt file to a Dataflow job in performance tests you are running, but there may be a better option. Thank you.

column3:
https://numpy.org/doc/1.18/reference/random/legacy.html

",17036145,kamilwu,"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 11:35:11 +0000","

Thanks tvalentyn, great work!

column1:
I'll take a look at this in the next couple of days. I'll keep you posted on any progress.

",17036377,tvalentyn,"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 17:46:24 +0000","

Thanks, kamilwu. I'll reassign the issue to you for now, for the follow-up changes in the test infra.

",,,,,,,,,,,,17036457,tvalentyn,"Thu, 13 Feb 2020 19:32:47 +0000","

note that passing numpy==1.16.5 in requirements.txt increases the installation time on Dataflow workers in Python 3 tests. Looking at worker startup logs, it takes about ~8 min to install numpy form sources that are staged, which makes Py3 tests appear slower than Py2 if judged by walltime (537s (py2) vs 977s (py3+requirements file to downgrade numpy)).

",17037199,tvalentyn,"Fri, 14 Feb 2020 18:50:12 +0000","

I also tried running the experiment on Dataflow runner with increased number of records, it appears that Py3 may still be somewhat slower, so we may have to come back to investigating this issue, after we address the slowdown in the synthetic input generator.

",17084101,kamilwu,"Wed, 15 Apr 2020 13:45:35 +0000","

I think we can close this ticket. tvalentyn Do you have any comments?

",,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,17084385,tvalentyn,"Wed, 15 Apr 2020 21:16:27 +0000","

No comments - the graphs in first message show an improvement in metrics, and Py3 Dataflow benchmarks are on par or better than Py2.

[BEAM-6810] [SQL] Plan optimizer eliminates aliasing in trivial projections,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6810,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Trivial programs project precisely their input fields, without dropping or re-ordering them. The simplest example is:

Given input PCollection with a schema `c_int64: BIGINT` following query should result in PCollection with a schema `abc: BIGINT`, however, due to a bug in query optimization, it results in `c_int64: BIGINT`
SELECT c_int64 as abc FROM PCOLLECTION

From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,yifanzou,Yifan Zou,tvalentyn,Valentyn Tymofieiev,"Tue, 16 Apr 2019 20:47:27 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:52:54 +0000","Fri, 19 Apr 2019 17:18:17 +0000",Not applicable,test-failures,testing,,0,2,16819584,yifanzou,"Tue, 16 Apr 2019 23:20:51 +0000","

Do you have an idea that how many CPUs will be consumed by the newly added Py3 tests? tvalentyn

",16819626,tvalentyn,"Wed, 17 Apr 2019 00:54:14 +0000","

Assumptions:

column1: • We have suites for Py 2.7, 3.5, 3.6, 3.7, which will run in parallel..
• PostCommit test suite will start up to 8 pipelines simultaneously,
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/4c322107ca5ebc0ab1cc6581d957501fd3ed9cc4/build.gradle#L200. AFAIK precommit test suite always runs 1 test at a time.
• Each Jenkins worker runs at most test 1 suite.

In this case the ballpark for the upper bound would be: 16 Jenkins machines * 4 Python minor versions * 8 pipelines per test suite = 512 vCPU cores.

",16822070,yifanzou,"Fri, 19 Apr 2019 17:18:17 +0000",

CPU quota in us-central1 has been increased to 1250.

The generated pom in the SNAPSHOTS repository points to dependencies that don't have the correct name, for example the beam-sdks-java-core pom points to

but such groupId and artifactId do not exist (and have not existed in the past).

",,13233261,BEAM-7302,Dependencies are broken in SNAPSHOT pom files,1,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21133&avatarType=issuetype,Bug,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,michel,Michael Luckey,iemejia,Ismaël Mejía,"Tue, 14 May 2019 15:18:42 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:52:51 +0000","Thu, 16 May 2019 08:47:39 +0000",Not applicable,build-system,,,0,4,16839651,kenn,"Tue, 14 May 2019 17:36:22 +0000","

I expect the problem is here: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/buildSrc/src/main/groovy/org/apache/beam/gradle/BeamModulePlugin.groovy#L1093

That line was not modified in https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/8194/ even though it probably needs to be

",16839656,kenn,"Tue, 14 May 2019 17:41:22 +0000","

But this makes me wonder - if we set things up correctly with publishing plugin, why would be be manually building the pom.xml?

",16839738,iemejia,"Tue, 14 May 2019 19:53:47 +0000","

Maybe lcwik knows the reason.

",Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|z02oe8:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,,,0,0h,4200,1h 10m,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,2.14.0,,,16839762,lcwik,"Tue, 14 May 2019 20:32:40 +0000","

The dependencies were originally rewritten because the groupId/artifactId were incorrect when publishing the pom.xml. Eventually the reason as to why they were rewritten was so we could add the exclusions on each dep to prevent things like guava-jdk5 from being pulled in transitively. If the publish plugin can now handle this, we could remove a bunch of the rewriting logic.

",16839771,michel,"Tue, 14 May 2019 20:39:15 +0000","

Thx, kenn for jumping in. Agree on the cause. I am actually wondering, how this slipped through. Going to merge this to fix the current issue and will further look whether that rewriting is still required.

",16839886,michel,"Wed, 15 May 2019 00:23:35 +0000","

Unfortunately, as long as we use shadow plugin, we probably need to manually configure our deps. See https://imperceptiblethoughts.com/shadow/publishing/#publishing-with-maven-plugin

",16840452,michel,"Wed, 15 May 2019 14:21:06 +0000","

After short investigating, it seems neither components.java nor shadow.component(publication) [
column3: will satisfy our requirements. So I suggest we keep that manually build pom.xml for the time being.

column1: Will only slightly modify to fix `generatePomFileForMavenJavaPublication` task, which is currently broken as it does not configured dependent upon project, i.e. archivesBaseName is unset.

column3:
https://github.com/johnrengelman/shadow/blob/master/src/main/groovy/com/github/jengelman/gradle/plugins/shadow/ShadowExtension.groovy#L19-L37

",16841127,iemejia,"Thu, 16 May 2019 08:47:15 +0000","

I want to confirm this is fixed now. Thanks michel and kenn for the quick fix.

",16841377,michel,"Thu, 16 May 2019 14:02:16 +0000","

FYI: Opened PR 8594 to fix generatePomFileForMavenJavaPublication

[BEAM-10164] Flink: Memory efficient combine implementation for batch runner,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-10164,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Current Combine implementation assumes that all input values for a single key (on both map and reduce side) fit in memory as it needs to sort them by window before combining.

We can easily optimize this for non-merging windows by pre-grouping elements by (K, W) tuples.

[BEAM-6997] LTS backport: No messages delivered after a while with PubsubIO,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6997,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

I am running the following Beam pipeline code locally, with the FlinkRunner. PubsubIO is used to read messages from a topic. I have a separate thread that publishes messages to the topic at regular intervals (every 30 seconds) and also sets the ""ts"" attribute which is used later to derive the event time.
Custom transform to convert to KV pair -
Note that ""key"" is a key set in the message attributes earlier in the publisher thread. The intent is to group the messages downstream by this key.

The transforms are not chained for ease of reading. The KVPrinter transform in the end is just to print out the messages received from the group by, which will be subsequently replaced by actual code once I get this running. When I run this, I don't find the trigger executing for quite some time (a couple of minutes or longer). When it finally triggers, I see that some of the messages are not received (in the final step), not matter how long I keep it running. The Pubsub statistics in my GCP/Stackdriver dashboard show that there is a backlog of undelivered messages.
Is this due to the internal watermark that PubsubIO uses? My intention here is to make sure that all messages are processed in the groupby, including late ones within the allowed lateness window.
Note that if I remove the GroupByKey, and just print the messages after the windowing, I can see all the messages.

An update:  I switched the .fromTopic to a .fromSubscription, with a pre-created subscription, and things have started working, as in, I can see messages being delivered now. The only difference I can see is that the automatically created subscription from within PubsubIO has an ack deadline of 60 seconds, whereas I created mine with 600 seconds (the max allowed by pubsub).

However, there is another issue now - messages don't seem to be getting acked. I keep getting redeliveries of old messages, and the Stackdriver metrics show that the num_undelivered_messages (unacked messages count) keeps on increasing. The documentation says that messages will be acked as soon as a GroupByKey or another ParDo happens, and that's happening since I am seeing the windowed groupby-s, but acks don't seem to be happening.

[BEAM-7675] Unify test suite configuration structure across Py2 and Py 3 suites,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7675,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Currently most of Py27 test suites are defined in https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/python/build.gradle while Python 3.x suites are defined in runner-specific folders, for example https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/python/test-suites/direct/py35/build.gradle.

This may cause confusion (where to add a new suite) and divergence of tests suites, for example Direct runner postcommit suites on Python 2 and Python 3 are defined inconsistently https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7674

We should unify test structure to avoid confusion and consider reducing duplication of Gradle code if/when it makes sense to do so.

[BEAM-9078] Large Tarball Artifacts Should Use GCS Resumable Upload,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-9078,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

It's possible for the tarball uploaded to GCS to be quite large. An example is a user vendoring multiple dependencies in their tarball so as to achieve a more stable deployable artifact.
Before this change the GCS upload api call executed a multipart upload, which Google [
column3: (https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/json_api/v1/how-tos/upload) states should be used when the file is small enough to upload again when the connection fails. For large tarballs, we will hit 60 second socket timeouts before completing the multipart upload. By passing `total_size`, apitools first checks if the size exceeds the resumable upload threshold, and executes the more robust resumable upload rather than a multipart, avoiding

column1:
socket timeouts.

[BEAM-6603] Python Pre/PostCommit generate huge console log,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-6603,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

From the history of beam_PreCommit_Python_Cron, Huge console log are generated starting from this build. About 30MB console log is generated and most of them are INFO and DEBUG log from pipeline running. This causes console output load very slow and no gradle scan is available due to too large logs.
Three commit changes since last build seems not related to logging configuration. Not sure if it's related to other changes that's not listed there or the Jenkins update.

column2:
type=Code"" class=""external-link"" target=""_blank"" rel=""nofollow noopener"">`--nocapture` that's passed to integration tests, so that stdout will be captured by nose and only print if test fails. However, we should understand why those logs are enabled and control it properly.

",,13214069,BEAM-6603,Python Pre/PostCommit generate huge console log,1,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21133&avatarType=issuetype,Bug,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,markflyhigh,Mark Liu,markflyhigh,Mark Liu,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 03:25:05 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:52:17 +0000","Tue, 26 Feb 2019 19:44:35 +0000",Not applicable,build-system,testing,,0,2,16761972,markflyhigh,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 17:44:16 +0000","

Tried in https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/7752. Turns out disable --nocapture will not work. This may be a bug in Python 3 code since lots of debugging logs are generated from py3-gcp and directrunner py3 tests.

column1:
cc: tvalentyn ccy

",16762070,tvalentyn,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 20:02:49 +0000","

For some reason on python 3

includes DEBUG logs by default.

",16762079,markflyhigh,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 20:13:13 +0000","

True. I didn't see nose version change or nose command change to those tests recently. Py3 tests did not print INFO and DEBUG logs initially when they were added to Jenkins (for example this precommit cron build)

Reopened https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/7752 to disable log capture plugin so that no INFO and DEBUG logs will be printed out. The down side of this change is that those logs will not longer be available if test fails.

I think it's okay to disable in unit test and only print INFO for integration tests.

",Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|yi0p40:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,,,0,0h,12600,3.5h,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,16762093,tvalentyn,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 20:33:28 +0000","

Setting --logging-level=WARNING is a better way to fix it without removing logcapture. We do need the logs to debug and report flakes.

Interestingly, passing --logging-level=DEBUG on Python 2 to does NOT emit logs, so I suspect something is suppressing test log output on Python 2. There maybe some  hierarchy of rules that define what is printed or not, similar to one I observed in https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/6687#issuecomment-430907854, and perhaps this hierarchy is different on Python 2 and Python 3 due to rules defined in downstream dependencies.

",16762221,tvalentyn,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 22:58:32 +0000","

We looked at this together with markflyhigh - turns out, this excessive debug output in nose is triggered by a use of logging.warning() in setup.py: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/75eb411ee85a4cf3862d42ae3d6a705cc516709e/sdks/python/setup.py#L174

",16762234,tvalentyn,"Wed, 6 Feb 2019 23:21:05 +0000","

Using warnings.warn() does not give this side-effect. Curious, if altay ccy or robertwb have encountered this before or have an understanding why using 'logging' in setup.py has a sideffect on nose that makes it print all the logs.

[BEAM-7730] Add Flink 1.9 build target and Make FlinkRunner compatible with Flink 1.9,https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-7730,12319527,BEAM,Beam,"

Apache Flink 1.9 will coming and it's better to add Flink 1.9 build target and make Flink Runner compatible with Flink 1.9.
I will add the brief changes after the Flink 1.9.0 released.

And I appreciate it if you can leave your suggestions or comments!

",,13244492,BEAM-7730,Add Flink 1.9 build target and Make FlinkRunner compatible with Flink 1.9,2,https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&avatarId=21141&avatarType=issuetype,New Feature,10102,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg,P2,5,https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/resolved.png,"A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.",Resolved,3,done,green,1,Fixed,dmvk,David Morávek,sunjincheng121,sunjincheng,"Fri, 12 Jul 2019 02:32:47 +0000","Fri, 24 Jul 2020 19:52:14 +0000","Tue, 22 Oct 2019 10:11:56 +0000",2.17.0,runner-flink,,,1,10,16883483,sunjincheng121,"Fri, 12 Jul 2019 02:46:35 +0000","

Hi mxm I have been seen that the patch of Flink 1.7, 1.8 are contribution from you, I think you have a lot of experience in this area, I am interested to contribute beam on this ticket, So I appreciate it if you can give me some suggestions and guides.

",16883736,mxm,"Fri, 12 Jul 2019 11:55:50 +0000","

Hey sunjincheng121! Adding a new Flink build target is quite easy if there are no backwards-incompatible changes. You can see how it is done in the runners/flink/1.x directories which all inherit from the flink_runner.gradle base file with a few modifications to the source directories which may be version-specific.

Once we add the 1.9 target, we may want to remove 1.5 because we already build against four versions of Flink. There is some potential for simplification of the code because of 1.5 specific workarounds in the code. For example, there is the `preSnapshotBarrier` hook added in 1.6 that we had to workaround in 1.5 by buffering elements in `snapshotState` instead. However, you do not have to worry about this, we may do this separately.

",16884142,kedin,"Fri, 12 Jul 2019 20:07:31 +0000","

It doesn't look like a blocker for Beam 2.14, i'll mark it for 2.15 instead

",Development,customfield_12314020,com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary,Enable Automatic Patch Review,false,customfield_12313422,com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox,Global Rank,9223372036854775807,customfield_12310420,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,Rank,0|z04lg8:,customfield_12311820,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank,Rank (Obsolete),9223372036854775807,customfield_12310920,com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank,,,0,0h,45600,12h 40m,Blocker,,,,10032,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,13255038,BEAM-8157,is blocked by,,,,,16890181,davidmoravek,"Mon, 22 Jul 2019 14:01:33 +0000","

Already did some work on this as we need to start trying out Blink internally.
There are two issues introduced in 1.8.1 and 1.9, that need to be fixed in Flink in order to make tests green.

Also there are few API incompatibilities, that needs to be abstracted out, but it was relatively easy and I already have one last test failing. I'll share the progress soon to mitigate duplication of effort.

",16890219,davidmoravek,"Mon, 22 Jul 2019 14:40:55 +0000","

Current progress: https://github.com/dmvk/beam/tree/BEAM-7730

",16896569,yifanzou,"Tue, 30 Jul 2019 22:14:44 +0000",

Changed the fix version to 2.16 since this is not a blocker of incoming release.

,16897895,davidmoravek,"Thu, 1 Aug 2019 09:06:28 +0000","

Successfully tested 1.9 runner with an internal pipeline. Everything works as expected, when I allocate only one slot per task manager. In case of multiple slots, pipeline fails during de-serialization outputs of ParDo with sideoutputs.

The issue seems like one of the coder's reads more data from de-serialization stream than it should and we end up with BufferUnderflow. This is probably a bug in Beam's KryoCoder and has nothing to do with flink runner (it happens in prior versions too).

Portable test case is still the last one failing, will further investigate after the issue mentioned above.

",16898265,mxm,"Thu, 1 Aug 2019 18:33:16 +0000","

That sounds great. Thanks for your work dmvk. Looking forward to reviewing the code. I've reassigned the issue to you.

",16898277,mxm,"Thu, 1 Aug 2019 18:40:50 +0000","

sunjincheng121 I hope reassigning the issue to David is ok since it looks like his implementation is almost complete. If possible we could combine any code from your side or you could help reviewing David's PR. Thank you.

",,,,,,,Container,13255215,BEAM-8162,contains,12310060,16900109,davidmoravek,"Mon, 5 Aug 2019 14:09:32 +0000","

I've managed to solve the serialization issues. Those were on the pipeline's side, where we were accessing OutputCollector from a different thread. Will send an initial PR once Flink 1.9-rc1 gets released.

I am very sorry, since I plan to open PR after the release of 1.9, I did not pay attention to this JIRA. during my business trip in Germany and vacation in Taiwan!(I just returned to China today-night.）

I didn't develop any code, and the dmvk ’s PR overall looks very good. I will have look at the detail next week.
